title: Iteratee concept does not seem to be documented
body:
One of the nice features of lodash is that a huge number of its functions take *iteratees*. If I understand correctly, an iteratee is either a function or a simple data structure that describes how to create a simple function.  You can make your own functions accept iteratees by passing iteratee arguments through `_.iteratee`.

However, as far as I can tell, this is not actually documented anywhere in https://lodash.com/docs/

There are a huge number of references to iteratees, and `_.iteratee` is itself documented, but at no point does it actually define what an iteratee is or explain how the `_.iteratee` function relates to the things referred to as iteratees elsewhere in the docs.

title: [ QUESTION ] create modular lib like Lodash
body:
Hi,

I'm heavily interested by the principle of building a little 'utils' library which would be as modular as lodash ( => have the ability to import each function separately, without destructuring the global import ) .

I've read the source code but I don't get how the architecture allows it, nor how npm scripts achieve it.

Could you point out the files or the the ressources you use to do so ?

Since I wasn't able to choose a label, I made it on my own on the title ( please indicate me if i misread something ;) )

Cheers.

title: Design Question: Why the split for object vs array functions in 5.0?
body:
Personally, I think it's a good idea - so 👍 for that. 

I see lodash/lodash gets a lot of asking why a property called "length" breaks _.map, so that has to be part of it. 

Part of me wants to know if there is a deeper philosophical reason. My personal crusade is having people be explicit when decomposing objects - be it via an array literal, `object.keys()`,`object.entries()`, or the future` _.mapObject`. Either way you do it, Object and Array are different, and a developer needs to be somewhat thoughtful of that. 

Also wondering how much changes on the roadmap should be planned for - obviously would like to minimize the amount of re-factor needed to upgrade out apps. 

Also apologies if the issue tracker is not the right place for this - I did an exhaustive search of the repo and couldn't find anything that answered my question.

title: findIndex behaviour

`_.findIndex([{a: 1}], null)` returns 0.
Is this correct behavior? To my regret I expected to see -1.

title: SortBy Multiple array numbers
body:
Hey guys

I found a small issue or at least I think is an issue 😄 .

Basically I want to sort by an simple array but with multiple sorts:
```
sortBy([8, 20, 1], (m) => {
  return m === 1 ? [3, 1] : [0, m];
})
```
The result is `[20, 8, 1]`.

If I change the array to a array of objects
```
sortBy([{key: 8, field: 0}, {key: 20, field: 0}, {key:1, field: 1}], ['field', 'key'])
```
The result is 
```
[{key: 8, field: 0}, {key: 20, field: 0}, {key: 1, field: 1}]
```
So the second example is right but the first one I was expecting in the first example is to give the order `[8, 20, 1]`.

title: map does not work properely on the following data
Provide a optional initializer parameter in collection functions keyBy and groupBy
body: By default, collection functions `groupBy`, `keyBy` return JS objects, which prevents to use other key/value implementaions like `Map`. They could provide an optional initializer parameter that construct the key/value implementation that the user wants to be used and returned by the function, and defaults to JS object.

title: pick should allow deep paths?
Importing issue with lodash/fp
body:
I'm sorry to jump right in with code but I don't know how else to explain the situation. Not sure if it's a bug or something I'm doing wrong.

```
import { unzipWith as fpUnzipWith, add as fpAdd } from 'lodash/fp'
import { unzipWith as normalUnzipWith, add as normalAdd } from 'lodash'

fpUnzipWith(fpAdd, [[1,2,3]]) // returns 3 functions (incorrectly?)
fpUnzipWith(fpAdd, [[1,2,3], []]) // returns correctly [1, 2, 3]

normalUnzipWith([[1,2,3]], normalAdd) // returns correctly [1, 2, 3]
normalUnzipWith([[1,2,3], []], normalAdd) // returns correctly [1, 2, 3]
```
However, the first example works if I don't import and just `<script src>` a lodash/fp build.

```
_.unzipWith(_.add, [[1,2,3]]) // returns correctly [1, 2, 3]
```

title: Native Promise.resovle in a lodash flow fails
body:
Putting the native `Promise.resolve` into a lodash flow crashes.

```
const myFlow = _.flow(x => x + 1, Promise.resolve);
myFlow(10);

Uncaught TypeError: #<Window> is not a constructor
    at resolve (<anonymous>)
    at lodash.min.js:49
    at <anonymous>:1:1
```

~~Is there any reason this would happen? If I use other "Promise" implementations, this semantic works.~~

Checked it out -- the following fails as well:
```
Promise.resolve.call({}, 10)
VM177:1 Uncaught TypeError: #<Object> is not a constructor
    at Object.resolve (<anonymous>)
    at <anonymous>:1:17
(anonymous) @ VM177:1
```

Seems you can't pass the native `Promise.resolve` as a function to run ".call", at least in Chrome. You also cannot capture and call Promise. TIL. Closing this issue.

title: Update compareMultiple.js
body:
This PR extend sorting
Now available only lower case sorting `'asc' || 'desc'`
And after this PR will be ` 'asc' || 'desc' || 'ASC' || 'DESC'`
**Actual Result**
```
 const users = [
    { 'user': 'fred',   'age': 48 },
    { 'user': 'barney', 'age': 34 },
    { 'user': 'fred',   'age': 40 },
    { 'user': 'barney', 'age': 36 }
  ]
  // Sort by `user` in ascending order and by `age` in descending order.
 _.orderBy(users, ['user', 'age'], ['asc', 'desc'])
 // => objects for [['barney', 36], ['barney', 34], ['fred', 48], ['fred', 40]]

```
**Now will we can use**
```
  // Sort by `user` in ascending order and by `age` in descending order.
 _.orderBy(users, ['user', 'age'], ['ASC', 'DESC'])
 // => objects for [['barney', 36], ['barney', 34], ['fred', 48], ['fred', 40]]
```

title: es6 Single-Line Arrow Functions
body:
We've found that es6 single-line arrow function (without curly braces) don't work when used with Lodash's **_.forEach** (could be others, this is what we've encountered). They appear to only be working for one iteration of the loop, instead of for every iteration. 

Here's an example of what happens with Lodash:
![lodash foreach](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4010544/29530389-9090134a-8671-11e7-9b35-c5c5646a0fba.PNG)

Here's what happens when using native **forEach**. Note, the same behavior is obtained by using Lodash's **_.map**. This is the expected behavior. 
![native foreach](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4010544/29530394-95ed4ba0-8671-11e7-8439-81a9ec29b03b.PNG)

Please let us know if this is expected behavior, or if we can expect a patch to be submitted. Thanks!

title: customizable fp reduce arity and auto-curry
body:
Best explained with an example


    a = _.flow(
      _.reduce(_.add)
    )([1,2,3])
    // f(n,t,r)... expected: 6


This can be fixed with:

    a = _.flow(
      _.reduce(_.add, 0)
    )([1,2,3])


The docs say that if `accumulator` is not supplied, the first element would be used as the initial `accumulator` value.  With the fixed arity and auto-curry, it's hard not not supply the accumulator argument.

Is there a way to convert `lodash\fp\reduce` so that is has a fixed arity of 2 -- thus always returns a function, It would be easier to spot mistakes like this if the `collection` parameter was required to be applied in isolation to the function that reduce returns.

body: lodash is licensed as CC0, but the package.json and README.md say MIT.  This changes the package.json SPDX license identifier and README.md to match the actual license.

title: Thread last (clojure) support
body:
Using the `loadsh/fp` library, it could be very useful to add a function like `clojure`'s [thread-last](https://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/-%3E%3E).

For example:

```
fp_.threadLast(collection, [
    filterPositives,
    filterEvens,
    fp_.map(add5),
    fp_.sum,
])
```

Instead of:

```
fp_.compose([
    fp_.sum,
    fp_.map(add5),
    filterEvens,
    filterPositives,
])(collection)
```

title: add is defined() function
In FP all of the object iterators have capped iteratees
body: All of the object iterators (forIn, forInRight, mapKeys, mapValues, transform, etc..) now have capped iteratees. However, many times you need the object `keys` AND `values` when iterating over an object. Especially when order is not guaranteed. I don't believe this is a mistake as I see capping in the code and mentioned in the FP docs. Any suggestions? Oh BTW - FP is a GREAT improvement! Thanks!!

title: Inconsistent return value using `_.round`
body:
Using `_.round` you get `NaN` if you pass `undefined` as the first parameter but you get `0` if you pass `null`. This seems like an inconsistent behavior. I think in both cases it should return `NaN` (or maybe 0).

```js
_.round(null, 2); // returns 0
_.round(undefined, 2); // returns NaN
```

Thanks!

title: Possible memory leak with _.get(), _.set()
body:
I'm doing a bit of experimenting and it appears that the path values provided to `_.get({}, path)` are not being garbage collected. I'm not sure if this issues is in Lodash or in V8, or if it's even an issue at all. While sifting through heapdumps of an application which generates dynamic paths (e.g. `".x.y[id].z"`) I'm seeing a lot of these paths stick around.

Node.js: v8.2.1 / v6.11.2
Lodash: 4.17.4

Here we can reproduce the issue:
```
$ node --inspect --expose-gc
> var _ = require('lodash');
Expression assignment to _ now disabled.
undefined
> gc()
undefined
> process.memoryUsage().heapUsed.toLocaleString()
'6,757,728'
> _.get({}, '.leak'.repeat(Math.floor(Math.random() * 899999 + 100000)));
undefined
> _.get({}, '.leak'.repeat(Math.floor(Math.random() * 899999 + 100000)));
undefined
> _.get({}, '.leak'.repeat(Math.floor(Math.random() * 899999 + 100000)));
undefined
> _.get({}, '.leak'.repeat(Math.floor(Math.random() * 899999 + 100000)));
undefined
> gc()
undefined
> process.memoryUsage().heapUsed.toLocaleString()
'127,944,824'
```

We can even execute those `_.get()` calls in another stack and the memory still leaks.

```js
setTimeout(function() { _.get({}, '.leak'.repeat(Math.floor(Math.random() * 899999 + 100000)));}, 10);
```

While using the Chrome developer tools we can see the strings sticking around:

![2017-08-08-113707_593x285_scrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/551402/29088458-f8b2c74a-7c2d-11e7-82df-9a803e3ee37a.png)

Simply generating the strings doesn't cause them to stick around:

```
$ node --inspect --expose-gc
gc()
undefined
> process.memoryUsage().heapUsed.toLocaleString()
'5,597,176'
> void (x = '.leak'.repeat(Math.floor(Math.random() * 899999 + 100000)))
undefined
> x.length
3448415
> void (x = '.leak'.repeat(Math.floor(Math.random() * 899999 + 100000)))
undefined
> void (x = '.leak'.repeat(Math.floor(Math.random() * 899999 + 100000)))
undefined
> void (x = '.leak'.repeat(Math.floor(Math.random() * 899999 + 100000)))
undefined
> void (x = '.leak'.repeat(Math.floor(Math.random() * 899999 + 100000)))
undefined
> x.length
1498265
> delete x
true
> gc()
undefined
> process.memoryUsage().heapUsed.toLocaleString()
'5,700,472'
>                                                                             
```

title: Request: sortedFind
body:
Suppose one wants to perform a binary search on an array in order to find a non-primitive element.

Right now this is impossible in lodash without hand-rolling one's own binary search. However if it were possible to pass lodash a transformation, this would let people get at lodash's binary search capability.

For example, suppose a large sorted array of objects of the shape `{ value: Number }`. Unless I'm mistaken, there's no way to find a specific element except linearly. This need would be served by `_.sortedFind(arr, item => item.value)`.

This might need some workshopping, but basically if it were easier to access the binary search then a common pain point for me would be met.

title: `sortedUniq` does not return unique array if input is not sorted
body:
When using `sortedUniq` with a non sorted array the duplicates are not removed from the output. The documentation states that 

> This method is like `_.uniq` except that it's designed and optimized for sorted arrays.

that is wrong since it does not return a unique array if the input is not sorted.

```javascript
_.sortedUniq(["test1", "test2", "test3", "test4", "test1", "test2", "test3", "test4"])
``` 
returns `["test1", "test2", "test3", "test4", "test1", "test2", "test3", "test4"]` 
expected is `["test1", "test2", "test3", "test4"]`

title: _.pick() has (possibly) unintended behaviour when picking object properties that are objects
How to use `chain` with `lodash-es` while supports tree shaking?
body:
As we all know, [`lodash-es`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tree/es) is built with a more modular syntax for supporting tree shaking by build tools.

However, `chain` related features means some functions are attached to a object/prototype chain.

I can see `chain` is published with `lodash-es`, but I am not sure how to use it with proper imports with other chained method.

A usecase may look like this:

    import { chain } from 'lodash-es'
    
    export function double(input) {
        return chain(input)
            .without(null)
            .map(val => val * 2)
            .value()
            .join(', ')
    }

The point is not about how is `chain` imported, but about **how are other `chained` functions imported**.

> Here is a SO question created: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45462193/how-to-use-chain-with-lodash-es-while-supports-tree-shaking

### Further question:
What is the actual usecase of `chain` under `lodash-es`?
If we should not use `chain` under `lodash-es`, shouldn't it be published?

title: Means of creating keyByValue objects?
Is it possible to intersect an array of objects with itself, by property
body:
I have an array of location objects. I would like to check if two objects inside that array have the same country.

If I do `_.intersectionBy(locations, 'country')`, even objects which contain countries that are only mentioned once are selected:
```
let locations = [{country: 'Portugal'}, {country: 'China'}, {country: 'Portugal'}];
_.intersectionBy(locations, 'country');
```
returns ```[{country: 'Portugal'}, {country: 'China'}]```

When I think it would make sense to return only ```[{country: 'Portugal'}]```

title: remove unnecessary check
body:
I found an unnecessary check.
``` value = (comparator || value !== 0) ? value : 0```

If value is 0 then always return 0;
if value is not 0 then always return value;

I also write a simple code to prove my thought.
```
var origin = (comparator, value) => ((comparator || value !== 0) ? value : 0); 
var updated = (comparator, value) => value;

console.log(origin(false, 0) === updated(false, 0)); //true
console.log(origin(false, 1) === updated(false, 1)); //true
console.log(origin(true, 0) === updated(true, 0)); //true
console.log(origin(true, 1) === updated(true, 1)); //true
```

Hope this pull request can save some byte for lodash.

lodash.js / lodash.min.js: IBM AppScan finding: Web Application Source Code Disclosure Pattern Found
body:
IBM AppScan security testing tool (Standard 9.0.2.1, Rules: 1932) is flagging lodash.js and lodash.min.js as low severity issues.
The suspected code pattern is "<%".
Is this valid? If valid, how to fix?
I'm very inclined to define it as a false positive.

Other info from ApScan:
- Risk: It is possible to retrieve the source code of server-side scripts, which may expose the application
logic and other sensitive information such as usernames and passwords
- Causes: Latest patches or hotfixes for 3rd. party products were not installed
Temporary files were left in production environment
Debugging information was left by the programmer in web pages
- Fix: Remove source code files from your web-server and apply any relevant patches
- Reasoning: The response contains source code of script files, which may expose sensitive information
about the site and the application logic.

Questions about comments in baseIsNaN.js
body:
The baseIsNaN.js file is
```
/**
 * The base implementation of `isNaN` without support for number objects.
 * @private
 * @param {*} value The value to check.
 * @returns {boolean} Returns `true` if `value` is `NaN`, else `false`.
 */
function baseIsNaN(value) {
  return value !== value
}

export default baseIsNaN

```
I would like to know why he said "without support number objects"？

title: Why does `_.get(obj, path)` return `undefined` when path is empty?
body: I'd like to use `_.get(obj, path)` with generic paths, including empty ones to return the whole data structure. Unfortunately, when the path is empty (i.e., `''` or `[]`, or `null` or `undefined` for that matter), `baseGet` is hardwired to return `undefined`. Is there a specific reason for this? It isn't mentioned in the docs.

title: It would be nice if debounce time can be changed on debounced instance

title: _.isEmpty for boolean values
fp.partial not accepting simple values
body:
Documentation makes it seem like `fp.partial` optionally accepts an array, but it they're mandatory.

```js
const { partial } = require('lodash/fp')

const foo = partial((a, b) => a+b)([1])
foo(2) // ok

const foo = partial((a, b) => a+b)(1)
foo (2) // TypeError: CreateListFromArrayLike called on non-object
```

## From the documentation ([source](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/FP-Guide))

### Exceptions to the rules

##### Methods that accept an array as their last or only argument:
assignAll, assignAllWith, assignInAll, assignInAllWith, defaultsAll, defaultsDeepAll, invokeArgs, invokeArgsMap, mergeAll, mergeAllWith, partial, partialRight, without, & zipAll

title: Question: computed === computed
body:
I was looking through the source code and found this check:
`if (isCommon && computed === computed)` in [baseDifference.js](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/.internal/baseDifference.js#L47).

I'm wondering what `computed === computed` checks for. The only thing I could come up with where this would result in`false` is when the value of `computed` is `NaN`.

Is that what is going on?

title: _.update() docs grammar fix
body: "that accepts" -> "that it accepts"

title: add function _.forEachSync
body: i knew that the function _.forEach can  iterate over elements of collection and invokes iteratee for each element .  But if the function i pass in have some codes of async-functions , i want the function iterate synchronously  in order of the index of the array. So  i suggest that adding the function _.forEachSync  will be nice.

title: head is not lazy in fp
Can't loop through non-enumerable/Symbol keys
_.invert() throws an error on a specific JSON object
Add a _.shift function that shifts arguments
body:
Hey,

I have a simple use case where I use `cond` to basically emulate a switch. It gets called with the first argument being the *pivot* (a type defined as a `string`). I would then like to call different functions depending on the value of the *pivot*. All those functions are not interested by the *pivot*, but the rest of the arguments. I know I could use a simple object indexed by types, but I want a generic pattern that work when the *pivot* is a complex type (`object`, `function`, ...).

I've experimented several ways of doing so with Lodash and couldn't find a *simple* way. Perhaps I missed it, and if so sorry for the issue.

The only short way is to use splats like so:
```js
const handleActions = cond([
  [matches('create'), (type, ...args) => handleCreate(...args)]
])
```

My proposal would be to add a new `_.shift` function with the following signature: `_.shift(func, [increment=1])`

It would work as the `shift` operator but for args and would shift a given number of arguments defined by an `increment`. Depending of the sign of `increment`, those arguments would be shifted left or right. By default (and because it's the most common use case), a positive value would shift arguments to the left, a negative to the right.

Example use case:
```js
const add(a, b) => a + b
const sub(a, b) => a - b

const apply = cond([
  [matches('add'), shift(add)],
  [matches('sub'), shift(sub)]
])

apply('add', 1, 2)
// => 3
```

title: CurryRight with Reduce does not work correctly
lodash call all functions in array/object without collecting results
isMap does not work in Safari 9
body:
It appears the issue arrises when [lodash tries to use Node's util.isMap](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/isMap.js#L6) method to do the actual detection; this method does not exist. [Util's docs](https://nodejs.org/api/util.html) list all of the other is* methods as deprecated, so perhaps `isMap` has already been removed.

Meantime, the workaround we're using is `instanceof`:
```js
if (obj instanceof Map) // is a Map
```

I'm happy to send you a PR for isMap, but I think the deprecation of the other Util methods is likely to be a larger problem.

title: add function _.filterBlank
Undocumented parameter coercion
body:
Is this supposed to work this way?

```
var array = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'];
_.nth(array, '3.2'); // 'c'
```

title: fp: mapKeys not working with convert({cap: false})
body:
I'm using (and loving) fp.
But:
```
const fp = require('lodash/fp').convert({cap: false});
var test = {x: 1, y: 2};
print(fp.mapKeys(x=>x+x)(test));
```
Gives:
```{ '2': 1, '4': 2 }```

When leaving off `convert({cap: false})`, it prints the correct output:
```{ 'xx': 1, 'yy': 2 }```

title: Why is `sameValueZero` used by default?
body:
Hi!

I'm trying to found the decision to use `sameValueZero` as default comparison instead of strictly equal `===`. I don't know if using `sameValueZero` is something decided because is more intuitive (NaN is equal to NaN) or for other technical reasons that I don't know.

Thanks!
